description: The Toronto Railway Museum is dedicated to sharing the history and experience of rail transportation in Toronto and Ontario. The museum is located inside Stall 17 of the John Street Roundhouse National Historic Site Roundhouse Park. Don Station houses our gift shop and ticket sales for our Miniature Train ride. Join us for a guided tour of the train cars and buildings located onsite.

reviews.title: Riding the Rails
text: Have been here more than once. Is lovely when it is quiet and not full of rambunctious children as one can really take one's time but comes alive in summer. It's in one of the sheds, 17, in the roundhouse -  walk into a perfume of soot and oil and grease and metal and engine dust. Films of the golden age with Gordon Lightfoot's railway trilogy playing in the background, plaques, dishes, timetables, model railways, a squirrel running around, restoration going on on an engine they use to move the outside cars/rolling stock (engine #10). The Nova Scotia wooden passenger car named Sans Pareil ("without equal") parlour and dining car from 1896 of the DAR became the business car after major extension, for the DAR VP (private apartments, meeting room and office). It survived the 1917 Halifax explosion that caused the roof of the station to collapse on the car and the VP and his whole family were in it and survived... brass railings, horsehair insulation, viewing platforms. Inside focuses on the the Canadian National, Canadian Pacific and the Dominion Atlantic. Managed once to play with the train simulator, which I could have kept up for hours. Outside there are engines ad cars that, during the summer, can be clambered upon by child and adult alike. Engine 4803. Canadian Pacific Cape Race. Toronto Hamilton Buffalo Caboose. Huts and stations and track changing booths. There is a gift shop and a mini Go Train that runs around the park on a single track. Oh the days of yore!

reviews.title: Old rolling stock
text: I loved looking at the old Canadian Pacific trains and carriages. Some really old trains in a nice location near the station and CN tower

reviews.title: Great for a train nerd
text: Very expensive to go in for very little. The trains outside are free to look at and are great. If you're REALLY in to trains, you'll love it.

reviews.title: Indoor exhibit too small and expensive
text: This is an indoor/outdoor museum. The outdoor portion is free and great. The indoor part costs $14 and is small. Would recommend for rail fans only.

reviews.title: A Canadian Embarrassment
text: Nothing and I mean nothing to see at this "museum".
14 dollars for a "museum" you can view from the front door.  Photos, some old china, and some poorly researched and displayed wall displays.
Restorations?  Another joke.  This place is not capable of handling and or "restoring" railroad equipment.
The environment?  A bunch of yuppie breweries and restaurants in a historic railroad building.
The hotel room I booked is larger than this "museum".  Outdoors? A poor "collection" of locomotives and rolling stock.

The only attraction at this "museum" is the CN 6213, which I'm told has zero public access beyond the chain fence erected 10-15 feet around it.  No way to inspect the locomotive close up or even take a half decent photo.  So if you are a railfan, railroader, or someone with more than a passing interest in trains, locomotives, or railroading history, this is NOT the place for you.
The two girls who I guess act as museum "staff" are worthless.

I should've read these reviews before making the drive, paying for parking, and walking to this "museum".  The city of Toronto and Canada in general should be embarrassed calling this 10' x 8.5' room a "railroad museum".
Would NOT recommend.

reviews.title: Don't pay to go inside.
text: Don't waste your money going into the museum. The outdoor displays are free and there's next to nothing to see indoors.

reviews.title: Limited items on display, Not worth it.
text: To start off I did not enter the museum.  On this day (11 June 2023) the attendants informed that the extent of the museum was what you saw as you are at the entrance, and the fee was $14 (est 200+ X 100 ft) not worth it.
Too bad, train museums are a favourite of mine.

reviews.title: Nice
text: Nice place to stop by if you are walking through the area, but that is pretty much it. You have the CN Tower and other attractions around it, so if you are going to one of those and want to check this one out, it is worth a quick stop.

reviews.title: Nice small museum
text: A small museum displaying railroad memorabilia. there is a larger outdoor display that does not require an admission ticket.
Steam Whistle Brewery is next door as well as a restaurant run by the brewing company.

reviews.title: A tiny Museum.
text: The best part was riding to the miniature train even though it only took 6-8 minutes.

The museum was tiny. It would have been far better if there was more to see. I would not say it was worth the trip all the way downtown. It is not an easy place to get to. The turntable with a train on it was interesting. You can see the entire place in well under 1 hour.

reviews.title: Great little railway museum
text: There are lots of exhibits outside and a small enclosed museum which is wheelchair accessible.  Very helpful staff and not expensive.  The signage and interpretation on the outside exhibits was much better than at some much bigger museums.  Very interesting to learn something of the history of the railways in Toronto and Ontario.  Close to the main station and CN tower so worth taking it in whilst visiting that area.  The miniature train seemed to be providing enjoyment for both children and parents.

reviews.title: great place for kids who love trains
text: Went here with my young boy who loves trains, had a great day out, its close to the CN tower and main train station so easy to get too, plus they have a nice little train outside which my boy loved going on a ride waving at  people.

reviews.title: Very Interesting
text: Had the opportunity to check out the Toronto Railway Museum..Brian was very informative and answered all the questions we asked..So much history to be learned..Got to go inside some of the trains and just blown away how far things have changed. I highly recommend checking this place out..Everyone is so nice there!

reviews.title: Interesting External displays
text: We were a little late to visit the museum which closes at 5pm, so were limited to walking the Railway Heritage Center which is outside of the museum. We are very interested in the history of railroads, and had visited many railroad museums while travelling through Siberia the previous year. There were 11 items on display in the area outside the museum, which was the main hub of the railway transport system at Union Station. It was initially the hub for steam trains, and was probably at its' peak of activity in the 1940's. As  steam trains made way for more modern diesel engines, the station gradually lost it's importance. It used to cover a huge area of downtown Toronto, but this Heritage Center and Museum are all that now remains.

It is free to walk amongst the external displays, and all have signboards to explain their historical significance. The displays included the coaling tower, roundhouse, turntable, watchman's shanty, Cabin D, Don Station and Water Tower. There were quite a few trains in addition to the layout of the buildings. Train types included U-2g steam locomotive, wooden tank car, Alco S-2 (the first diesel electric locomotive in Toronto), 1929 model of a first class carriage and a 1931 sleeper carriage. We thought that the displays were well presented, and regret missing the museum.
Other nearby attractions include Ripleys Aquarium and CN Tower.

reviews.title: Nice little museum, small but with lots of info
text: Nice place next to cn tower. The museum itself is quite small, but it has some interesting content. It's really good  place  for Railroad lovers.Got cool trains and you can go inside some of them . Tour guides were really nice and helpful. There  was also the miniature railway for kids, which goes on fully functional mini train tracks.

reviews.title: Nice place to visit with kids
text: Came here to look round and there is lots to look at around the outside of the train museum if you want to go inside it’s only $5 adults $3 seniors. Very good value if you have kids you can take a train ride around the outside area.

reviews.title: The train ride is the best for kids !
text: This is near the CN Tower and is a great place for a nice small train ride for kids. There are train cars on display but the ride is the best (you have to pay a fee for that).

reviews.title: We did NOT go in
text: We had about 2 hours before a concert at ScotiaBank Arena and thought about going in to take a look around. We decided to look at the train cars that are outside first before going in.  The have brick walkway all around out front and some are missing.  As we made our way around, I stepped into a spot where some bricks were missing and twisted my ankle pretty bad. My wife thought at first that I had broken it.  It was so bad, that we never did make into the museum and actually had to take a cab to the arena (all of about 3 blocks)  No orange cones around the "pothole", caution tape or even high visible spray paint AND it wasn't the only pothole we noticed while leaving the yard.  I can imagine i'm not the only one who's missed their step while walking around.
Fix your walkway before your museum gets sued!!

reviews.title: Family Holiday 2019
text: Took my family there and my year old son absolutely loved it. It’s reasonably priced though I didn’t really see much. My daughter chaperoned him. My son was very inquisitive and absolutely adored it.

reviews.title: A big let down
text: Claimed to b the canadian railway museum...it is nothing but a collection of 2 / 3 engines and uniforms and telephone instruments. Next to the CN tower but can b avoided

reviews.title: Small But Mighty!
text: This railway museum doesn't look like much because it is so small, but I gave it 5 stars because my grandsons absolutely loved it and wanted to go back the next day. They have a simulator there that you can try to drive a train by yourself. Both my grandsons really enjoyed that. Lots to read about the Canadian Railway in the exhibits, also. Highly recommended if your child is a train lover!

reviews.title: Not worth it
text: My 8 year old daughter and I were at Ripley's Aquarium and decided to check out the museum afterwards. There were 2 employees working and we were the only 2 visitors in the museum. There was a part inside a train that was chained off saying that part was closed for the day. We asked since we were the only ones there, could they take us in and make an exception and they said no. It was not under construction or anything, they just didn't want to. I understand if it was busy but it was dead inside. Even though the visit was only 8 bucks it wasnt worth it. The best part is the free trains outside.

reviews.title: DOESN’T TAKE TOO LONG
text: The museum to set in a lovely green area in the centre of the hustle and bustle of Toronto. It’s very close to the CN Tower, and although it doesn’t take too long to get around it’s worth the small charge to enter.

reviews.title: A small museum, but interesting.
text: We looked in on this museum after a visit to the CN Tower. It is located just below the Tower. A small indoor display area within an old engine roundhouse plus a number of outdoor exhibits. It gives the impression of being an enthusiast-led operation and this is a big plus. The items on display are an eclectic mix of serious history plus child entertainment. That said there is material here on regional railway history that could keep the serious railway buff engaged for at least an hour. And with an entry fee of $C5 what is there to complain about?.

reviews.title: a  small but interesting Museum
text: We enjoyed seeing the old Roundhouse and the collection of old rolling stock- no charge. The little museum costs $3 so not much money- it didn't take me long to walk round.

reviews.title: Great Setting
text: The museum is located in an old roundhouse. It is right across the street from the CN Tower, Aquarium, and Rogers Centre. The museum itself is very small and crowded. With admission you can tour some of the railroad cars scattered around the grounds at specific times. There is a small children's play area, model trains, railroad memorabilia and gift shop located in the museum. The roundhouse grounds itself are interesting especially if you never seen a railroad roundhouse and turntable. I've only seen them in books. There are many railroad cars and locomotives scattered around.

reviews.title: Fun find
text: We had no idea this was tucked away behind the aquarium until our Uber driver dropped us off there.  The interior of the museum didn't open until noon so we were too early to see that part, but we really enjoyed seeing the trains and the roundhouse.  There is a good bit to see and is something that kids would definitely enjoy.  We did not see any trains that you could go into to look at but that may have been due to us being too early.  I looked up the museum when we got back to our hotel room and it is only $5 for adults and I think kids would love the mini train and the simulator.

reviews.title: Cool trains, and a welcome alternative to the aquarium crowds!
text: After exiting the CN tower, we bypassed the line at he Aquarium and headed over to the Railway Museum.  Though I believe you can explore the trains outside without paying admission (I could be wrong), the small admission price of  $5 to access the small but very cool interior is well worth the contribution toward this non profit.  The roundhouse building itself is now mixed use (housing the rec room and steamwhilstle brewing), but it seemed the museum preserved the original feel of the round house.  There was an interactive simulation exhibit where you could learn to engineer a train, and lots of old signs and artifacts (like from the queens visit).  We didn't do the little train ride outside which was an extra fee, but it looked like fun for the wee ones.

reviews.title: Great place for kids
text: Found by accident after trip to CN tower. Kids enjoyed more than the tower! Loved miniature train ride and being able to climb onto engines. Near a small playground. Great inexpensive afternoon out.

reviews.title: Interesting but small
text: The Toronto Railway Museum is located in part of what used to be a round-house downtown, back in the day. There isn't much room but they make the most of it, including a special area for children. There are several engines and cars outside, but none open to view; also a small gift shop.

reviews.title: Don’t waste your time
text: We decided to wait in line for the Railway Museum and we were completely disappointed once we got inside. There were only few pictures on the walls and half a rail car to explore after you get inside. In addition, you have to pay $1 for a mask if you don’t bring one. (Not stated on the entrance) We immediately demanded our money back. Please don’t waste your time here.

reviews.title: Nice trains on the outside, but ticket buyers beware!
text: The outdoor train roundhouse and exhibits were interesting and well done. However, when I entered the small door at stall 17 which was advertised with a sign as the actual train museum I got quite a shock. After paying $10 and entering, I soon realized that this was just a very small room with only a few train artifacts. It was basically a room used to trap tourists into paying $10 each. I requested a refund and only after enduring arguments that I should pay because I had already seen the whole museum, even though it was tiny and contained nothing much of consequence. This was obviously a ploy to extract $10 from unknowing tourists to pay for seeing the trains on display on the outside the museum. It is very dishonest and the organization which devised this setup should be embarrassed by the trickery.

reviews.title: Overpriced Dismal Display
text: We (2 couples) decided to pay a visit to the railway museum as part of a wider trip to Toronto. Based on the old rolling stock outside the museum, we were looking forward to what was on offer inside. As soon as we stepped inside, we knew we had made a mistake. The 10 dollar per person entry fee which had seemed OK beforehand suddenly became a king's ransom. There was a quarter of a large hanger given over to some very lacklustre exhibits - many of which weren't working. There were two carriages to explore but there was really nothing of interest and aside the train simulator (which I think was intended for children but we were scraping the barrel by this point), there was nothing to illuminate what must have been such an important part of the City's history. We challenged the fee but the woman on the desk has probably heard it a thousand times before and was adept at some corporate spiel to try and justify it. We stayed 20 minutes max and that was with making every effort to try and see beyond the dully displayed information. 40 dollars for 20 minutes. Definitely not worth it and what a missed opportunity to create something of interest and even excitement for the many people who love trains and train history. Stick to looking at the trains outside if you do go (it's fee) and enter at your own peril ...

reviews.title: An OK 30 minutes experience
text: We didn't plan to visit the museum, but the outdoor (free) trains were fun to watch and board, so we thought that there were more fun activities waiting inside. We were disappointed to see that there were no children activities other than a few coloring sheets. The place was pretty small and we finished in about 30 minutes, but for $30 for a family of 4 it's fine.

reviews.title: outdoor trains great...but the train museum that you have to pay for it a rip off
text: Our grandson loves trains.  So after the aquarium we wondered around looking at the outdoor trains.

We saw the indoor museum, and from the door you can see other train cars, that look like you can see closer.  Nope, and nope.  There is just a very, very small museum that they charge $10 for adults and $5 for the grandson.
From the door of the museum is all that you will be able to see, nothing in the back or side you can go to.  We were done in about 5-7 minutes.  We felt it was a rip off.  Do not go this one.

reviews.title: Outdoor Railway Heritage Exhibit
text: Just fronting the CN Tower and Ripley’s Aquarium is an outdoor exhibit with displays of railroad cars and locomotive engines. Liked that they charge nothing for this museum , and that it somehow retain its previous history and heritage . I noticed however that the indoor portion was closed . Is it because of winter. But I loved strolling around and taking photos .

reviews.title: A must for railroad fans
text: Son loved it from the get go.  Watching the roundhouse work to the engine simulator. A little bit for everyone who loves trains

reviews.title: Nice spot near CN Tower
text: My partner & I toured the outdoor portion of this display of old train engines and cars just south of Yonge Street . The railroad cars are spread out in the small park and though we didn’t visit there is a small indoor part of the museum. Good place to take the kids.

reviews.title: A lot of outdoor exhibits
text: This museum is located just below the CN Tower. There are a lot of outdoor exhibits in the Roundhouse Park and it is free to walk there. It is definitely worth a visit even if you are not a big train lover.

reviews.title: Awesome Spot Before a Game
text: We walked over to Roundhouse Park to grab a snack before a Blue Jays game (we were in town for the day for the game), and it was awesome.  It's an old train roundhouse with train cars everywhere.  Most of the garage areas have been converted into restaurants or breweries.  It's an awesome place to let your kids play, grab a bite or a brew and just chill.
